Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 1: How can the diversity of materials be explained?

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 1: How can the diversity of materials be explained?
ContentDescription: The development and use of materials for specific purposes is an important human endeavour. In this unit students investigate the chemical structures and properties of a range of materials, including covalent compounds, metals, ionic compounds and polymers. They are introduced to ways that chemical quantities are measured. They consider how manufacturing innovations lead to more sustainable products being produced for society through the use of renewable raw materials and a transition from a linear economy towards a circular economy.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 1: How can the diversity of materials be explained?
ContentDescription: Students conduct practical investigations involving the reactivity series of metals, separation of mixtures by chromatography, use of precipitation reactions to identify ionic compounds, determination of empirical formulas, and synthesis of polymers.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 1: How can the diversity of materials be explained?
ContentDescription: Throughout this unit students use chemistry terminology including symbols, formulas, chemical nomenclature and equations to represent and explain observations and data from their own investigations and to evaluate the chemistry-based claims of others.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 1: How can the diversity of materials be explained?
ContentDescription: A student-directed research investigation into the sustainable production or use of a selected material is to be undertaken in Area of Study 3. The investigation explores how sustainability factors such as green chemistry principles and the transition to a circular economy are considered in the production of materials to ensure minimum toxicity and impacts on human health and the environment. The investigation draws on key knowledge and key science skills from Area of Study 1 and/or Area of Study 2.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on elements as the building blocks of useful materials.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
Elaboration: They investigate the structures, properties and reactions of carbon compounds, metals and ionic compounds, and use chromatography to separate the components of mixtures.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
Elaboration: They use metal recycling as a context to explore the transition in manufacturing processes from a linear economy to a circular economy.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to investigate the properties and reactions of various materials.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
Elaboration: Students may conduct flame tests to identify elements in the periodic table.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
Elaboration: They may model covalent, metallic and ionic structures using simple ball-and-stick models and may use computer simulations of the three-dimensional representations of molecules and lattices to better understand structures.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
Elaboration: They use solubility tables to experimentally identify unknown ions in solution.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
Elaboration: They respond to challenges such as developing their own reactivity series by reacting samples of metals with acids, oxygen and water.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to explain how elements form carbon compounds, metallic lattices and ionic compounds, experimentally investigate and model the properties of different materials, and use chromatography to separate the components of mixtures.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentHeader: How do the chemical structures of materials explain their properties and reactions?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 1 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on the measurement of quantities in chemistry and the structures and properties of organic compounds, including polymers.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to quantify amounts of substances and to investigate the chemistry of organic compounds.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
Elaboration: They perform calculations based on the generation of primary data, such as determining the empirical formula of an ionic compound or hydrated salt, and consider how the quality of data generated in experiments can be improved.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
Elaboration: They may construct models to visualise the similarities and differences between families of organic compounds.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
Elaboration: Students may use common substances in their experiments such as making glue from milk.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
Elaboration: They may investigate the environmental impact of the production of polymers: for example, the recycling of biodegradable polymers derived from natural resources such as biopolyethene (Bio-PE).

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
Elaboration: Students respond to challenges such as investigating how changing formulations for polymers affects their structure and properties: for example, by creating slime.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to calculate mole quantities, use systematic nomenclature to name organic compounds, explain how polymers can be designed for a purpose, and evaluate the consequences for human health and the environment of the production of organic materials and polymers.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentHeader: How are materials quantified and classified?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 2 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentDescription: Knowledge of the structure and properties of matter has developed over time through scientific and technological research, leading to the production of a range of useful chemicals, materials and products for society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Chemists today, through sustainable practices, seek to improve the efficiency with which natural resources are used to meet human needs for chemical products and services.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Chemists also learn from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples about the ways that they sustainably modify and process raw materials using techniques developed over millennia.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Sustainability requires innovation in designing and discovering new chemicals, production processes and product management systems that will provide increased yield or performance at a lower cost while meeting the goals of protecting and enhancing human health and the environment.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students undertake an investigation involving the selection and evaluation of a recent discovery, innovation, advance, case study, issue or challenge linked to the knowledge and skills developed in Unit 1 Area of Study 1 and/or Area of Study 2, including consideration of sustainability concepts (green chemistry principles, sustainable development and the transition towards a circular economy).

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Examples of investigation topics and possible research questions are provided below.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentDescription: Students may select a research question related to the investigation topics included below or, in conjunction with their teacher, develop their own research question related to Unit 1 Area of Study 1 and/or Area of Study 2.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Possible starting points when developing a research question may include visiting a chemical laboratory, local chemical manufacturer or industrial plant; announcements of recent materials science research findings; an interview with an expert involved in materials science or sustainability; an expert’s published point of view; a public concern about an issue related to the production of a chemical or material; ‘green field’ research leading to new technologies; changes in government funding or policy or new government initiatives, such as incentives promoting the transition from a linear economy to a circular economy; case studies related to how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples process natural materials for particular purposes; a TED talk; a YouTube presentation; or an article from a scientific publication.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentDescription: Students apply critical and creative thinking and science inquiry skills to prepare a communication to explain the relevant chemical concepts associated with their investigation, critically examine the information and data available to answer the research question, and identify the sociocultural, economic, political, legal and ethical implications of the selected investigation in terms of sustainability.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentDescription: Today’s chemists are involved in many branches of chemistry, covering all 118 elements in the periodic table.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Some of these elements are now considered to be critical and endangered, particularly due to the prevalence of modern technologies that rely on many different scarce minerals.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration:
It has been estimated that 
44 elements will soon be, or are already, facing supply limitations, making a future of continuing technological advancement uncertain.

ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: The cells in animals and plants are built of, and metabolise, natural polymers.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Proteins and carbohydrates in our food are both polymers.

ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration:
Synthetic polymers are used for a myriad of purposes in everyday life but may present challenges in terms 
of the by-products resulting from their manufacture or breakdown, and their persistence in the environment.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: The sustainability of polymers can be considered in terms of whether these plastics can be avoided by using different products or activities, reduced through design, or replaced by different materials.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?

ContentHeader: How can chemical principles be applied to create a more sustainable future?
Elaboration: Increasingly, manufacturing companies are moving towards a circular economy, which seeks to reduce the environmental impacts of production and consumption while enabling economic growth through more productive use of natural resources and creation of less waste.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 2: How do chemical reactions shape the natural world?

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 2: How do chemical reactions shape the natural world?
ContentDescription: Society is dependent on the work of chemists to analyse the materials and products in everyday use. In this unit students analyse and compare different substances dissolved in water and the gases that may be produced in chemical reactions. They explore applications of acid-base and redox reactions in society.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 2: How do chemical reactions shape the natural world?
ContentDescription: Students conduct practical investigations involving the specific heat capacity of water, acid-base and redox reactions, solubility, molar volume of a gas, volumetric analysis, and the use of a calibration curve.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 2: How do chemical reactions shape the natural world?
ContentDescription: Throughout the unit students use chemistry terminology, including symbols, formulas, chemical nomenclature and equations, to represent and explain observations and data from their own investigations and to evaluate the chemistry-based claims of others.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 2: How do chemical reactions shape the natural world?
ContentDescription: A student-adapted or student-designed scientific investigation is undertaken in Area of Study 3. The investigation involves the generation of primary data and is related to the production of gases, acid-base or redox reactions, or the analysis of substances in water. It draws on the key science skills and key knowledge from Unit 2 Area of Study 1 and/or Area of Study 2.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on understanding the properties of water and investigating acid-base and redox reactions.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration: They explore water’s properties, including its density, specific heat capacity and latent heat of vaporisation.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration: They write equations for acid-base and redox reactions, and apply concepts including pH as a measure of acidity.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration: They explore applications of acid-base reactions and redox reactions in society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to investigate the properties of water and acid-base and redox reactions.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration: They may demonstrate their understanding of concentration using coloured solutions such as ammonium molybdate.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration: Students explore pH: for example, by making their own indicators from natural materials, developing their own pH scale and comparing the accuracy of their indicators with commercial indicators.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration: They may investigate redox reactions by comparing corrosion rates of iron in tap water and sea water or building simple cells to power a diode.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
Elaboration:
They respond to challenges such as investigating the action of soda water on seashells and linking their findings to socio-scientific issues such 
as ocean acidification.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to explain the properties of water in terms of structure and bonding, and experimentally investigate and analyse applications of acid-base and redox reactions in society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentHeader: How do chemicals interact with water?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 1 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on the analysis and quantification of chemical reactions involving acids, bases, salts and gases.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
Elaboration: They measure the solubility of substances in water, explore the relationship between solubility and temperature using solubility curves, and learn to predict when a solute will dissolve or crystallise out of solution.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
Elaboration: They quantify amounts in chemistry using volumetric analysis, application of the ideal gas equation, stoichiometry and calibration curves.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to investigate substances that may be dissolved in water or found in soils, particularly salts, acids and bases, as well as gases.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
Elaboration: They use precipitation reactions to purify water: for example, by using iron or aluminium compounds to precipitate and remove phosphorus from wastewater.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
Elaboration: They perform acid-base titrations, such as comparing the ethanoic acid concentrations of vinegar, mayonnaise and tomato sauce.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
Elaboration: They construct calibration curves to analyse unknown concentrations of substances, such as the amount of nitrates or phosphates in water or soil samples.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
Elaboration:
Students respond to challenges such as determining the set of standards required in setting up 
a calibration curve in colorimetry.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to calculate solution concentrations and predict solubilities, use volumetric analysis and instrumental techniques to analyse for acids, bases and salts, and apply stoichiometry to calculate chemical quantities.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentHeader: How are chemicals measured and analysed?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 2 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

ContentHeader: How do quantitative scientific investigations develop our understanding of chemical reactions?

ContentHeader: How do quantitative scientific investigations develop our understanding of chemical reactions?

ContentHeader: How do quantitative scientific investigations develop our understanding of chemical reactions?

ContentHeader: How do quantitative scientific investigations develop our understanding of chemical reactions?

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How do quantitative scientific investigations develop our understanding of chemical reactions?

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 3: How can design and innovation help to optimise chemical processes?

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 3: How can design and innovation help to optimise chemical processes?
ContentDescription: The global demand for energy and materials is increasing with world population growth. In this unit students investigate the chemical production of energy and materials. They explore how innovation, design and sustainability principles and concepts can be applied to produce energy and materials while minimising possible harmful effects of production on human health and the environment.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 3: How can design and innovation help to optimise chemical processes?
ContentDescription: Students analyse and compare different fuels as energy sources for society, with reference to the energy transformations and chemical reactions involved, energy efficiencies, environmental impacts and potential applications. They explore food in the context of supplying energy in living systems. The purpose, design and operating principles of galvanic cells, fuel cells, rechargeable cells and electrolytic cells are considered when evaluating their suitability for supplying society's needs for energy and materials. They evaluate chemical processes with reference to factors that influence their reaction rates and extent. They investigate how the rate of a reaction can be controlled so that it occurs at the optimum rate while avoiding unwanted side reactions and by-products. Students conduct practical investigations involving thermochemistry, redox reactions, electrochemical cells, reaction rates and equilibrium systems.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 3: How can design and innovation help to optimise chemical processes?
ContentDescription: Throughout the unit students use chemistry terminology, including symbols, formulas, chemical nomenclature and equations, to represent and explain observations and data from their own investigations and to evaluate the chemistry-based claims of others.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 3: How can design and innovation help to optimise chemical processes?
ContentDescription: A student-designed scientific investigation involving the generation of primary data related to the production of energy and/or chemicals and/or the analysis or synthesis of organic compounds is undertaken in either Unit 3 or Unit 4, or across both Units 3 and 4, and is assessed in Unit 4 Outcome 3. The design, analysis and findings of the investigation are presented in a scientific poster format as outlined on pages 14 and 15.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on analysing and comparing a range of fossil fuels and biofuels as energy sources for society, and carbohydrates, proteins and lipids as fuel sources for the body.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: They write balanced thermochemical equations for the combustion of various fuels.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: The amounts of energy and gases produced in combustion reactions are quantified using stoichiometry.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: They explore how energy can be sustainably produced from chemicals to meet the needs of society while minimising negative impacts on the environment.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to investigate how energy from fuels can be obtained and measured, and to determine the efficiency of different fuels and electrochemical cells as sources of energy.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: They may measure energy released in combustion reactions through quantitative calorimetry experiments and may compare amounts of energy released in different fuels, such as methane, alcohols, waxes and foods.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: They design, construct and test galvanic and fuel cells, and account for differences between experimental findings and predictions made by using the electrochemical series.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: Students may work collaboratively to construct electrochemical half-cells and experiment with different combinations of half-cells to develop their own electrochemical series.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
Elaboration: Students respond to challenges such as designing an electrochemical cell that generates the most energy under laboratory conditions using a limited range of supplied chemicals and materials.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to compare fuels quantitatively with reference to combustion products and energy outputs, apply knowledge of the electrochemical series to design, construct and test primary cells and fuel cells, and evaluate the sustainability of electrochemical cells in producing energy for society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentHeader: What are the current and future options for supplying energy?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 1 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students explore the factors that affect the rate and yield of equilibrium and electrolytic reactions involved in producing important materials for society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: Reactants and products in chemical reactions are treated qualitatively through the application of Le Chatelier’s principle and quantified using equilibrium expressions, reaction quotients and Faraday’s Laws.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: Students explore the sustainability of different options for producing useful materials for society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to investigate equilibrium and electrolysis.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: They investigate reaction rates including the measurement of mass, gas volumes and time.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: They use an equilibrium system, such as iron(III) thiocyanate, to predict and test the effect of different changes to the system.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: They investigate the effect of catalysts on reaction rates, such as comparing the rate of decomposition of hydrogen peroxide using organic and inorganic catalysts.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: Students explore the application of electrolysis in the manufacture of useful products through experiments such as electroplating and anodising.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: They model and explain the operation of secondary cells: for example, those in portable devices such as laptops or cell phones.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: Students respond to challenges such as predicting and testing the optimum conditions under which a selected reaction can produce the highest product yield.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to experimentally analyse chemical systems to predict how the rate and extent of chemical reactions can be optimised, explain how electrolysis is involved in the production of chemicals, and evaluate the sustainability of electrolytic processes in producing useful materials for society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 2 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentDescription: Practical work is a central component of learning and assessment and may include activities such as laboratory experiments, fieldwork, simulations and other direct experiences as described in the scientific investigation methodologies on page 13.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
ContentHeader: How can the rate and yield of chemical reactions be optimised?
Elaboration: A minimum of 10 hours of class time should be devoted to student practical activities and investigations across Areas of Study 1 and 2.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 4: How are carbon-based compounds designed for purpose?

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 4: How are carbon-based compounds designed for purpose?
ContentDescription: Carbon is the basis not only of the structure of living tissues but is also found in fuels, foods, medicines, polymers and many other materials that we use in everyday life. In this unit students investigate the structures and reactions of carbon-based organic compounds, including considering how green chemistry principles are applied in the production of synthetic organic compounds. They study the metabolism of food and the action of medicines in the body. They explore how laboratory analysis and various instrumentation techniques can be applied to analyse organic compounds in order to identify them and to ensure product purity.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 4: How are carbon-based compounds designed for purpose?
ContentDescription: Students conduct practical investigations related to the synthesis and analysis of organic compounds, involving reaction pathways, organic synthesis, identification of functional groups, direct redox titrations, solvent extraction and distillations.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 4: How are carbon-based compounds designed for purpose?
ContentDescription: Throughout the unit students use chemistry terminology including symbols, formulas, chemical nomenclature and equations to represent and explain observations and data from their own investigations and to evaluate the chemistry-based claims of others.

Subject: Chemistry
ContentHeader: Unit 4: How are carbon-based compounds designed for purpose?
ContentDescription: A student-designed scientific investigation involving the generation of primary data related to the production of energy and/or chemicals and/or the analysis or synthesis of organic compounds is undertaken in either Unit 3 or Unit 4, or across both Units 3 and 4, and is assessed in Unit 4 Outcome 3. The design, analysis and findings of the investigation are presented in a scientific poster format as outlined on pages 14 and 15.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on the structure, naming, properties and reactions of organic compounds, including the chemical reactions associated with the metabolism of food.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
Elaboration: They explore how synthetic organic compounds can be produced more sustainably for use in society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to investigate organic structures and reactions.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
Elaboration: They may construct models to explore organic structures, including isomers.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
Elaboration: Students may compare the properties of biodiesels produced using different oils, or may investigate organic reaction pathways such as the synthesis of esters used in food flavourings.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
Elaboration: They may investigate food metabolism by hydrolysing different types of plant starches.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
Elaboration: Students respond to challenges such as how to improve the atom economy of a selected chemical reaction or reaction pathway.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the general structures and reactions of the major organic families of compounds, design reaction pathways for organic synthesis, and evaluate the sustainability of the manufacture of organic compounds used in society.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds categorised and synthesised?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 1 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on laboratory and instrumental analyses of organic compounds, and the function of some organic compounds as medicines.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: They use distillation to separate mixtures, use volumetric analysis to calculate redox quantities, and explore how instrumental analysis is used to ensure the quality of consumer products.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: Students explain how some medicines that bind to the active sites of enzymes function by inhibiting the enzymes’ mode of action.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentDescription: The selection of learning contexts should allow students to develop practical techniques to analyse organic compounds.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: Students develop their skills in the use of scientific equipment and apparatus.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: They may perform qualitative tests to identify features of organic compounds, such as the identification of functional groups in an unknown compound.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: Students may perform quantitative analyses including redox titrations to determine concentrations and quantities of substances, such as the amount of Vitamin C in fruits.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: They design and improve on experiments such as the testing of the viscosity of alcohols.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: They respond to challenges such as the identification of a molecule using primary data from analytical techniques used in the laboratory or secondary data obtained from spectroscopy.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
Elaboration: Students may use distillation to extract and purify the natural organic compounds in plants, such as extracting limonene from orange peel.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to apply qualitative and quantitative tests to analyse organic compounds and their structural characteristics, deduce structures of organic compounds using instrumental analysis data, explain how some medicines function, and experimentally analyse how some natural medicines can be extracted and purified.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentHeader: How are organic compounds analysed and used?
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 2 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry

ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentDescription:
Students undertake a student-designed scientific investigation in either Unit 3 or Unit 4, or across both 
Units 3 and 4.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
Elaboration: The investigation involves the generation of primary data related to the production of energy and/or chemicals and/or the analysis or synthesis of organic compounds, and should be inspired by a contemporary chemical challenge or issue.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
Elaboration: The investigation draws on knowledge and related key science skills developed across Units 3 and 4 and is undertaken by students in the laboratory and/or in the field.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentDescription: When undertaking the investigation students are required to apply the key science skills to develop a question, state an aim, formulate a hypothesis and plan a course of action to answer the question, while complying with safety and ethical guidelines.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
Elaboration: Students then undertake an experiment to generate primary quantitative data, analyse and evaluate the data, identify limitations of data and methods, link experimental results to scientific ideas, discuss implications of the results, and draw a conclusion in response to the question.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
Elaboration: The presentation format for the investigation is a scientific poster constructed according to the structure outlined on page 14.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
Elaboration: A logbook is maintained by students for recording, assessment and authentication purposes.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to design and conduct a scientific investigation related to the production of energy and/or chemicals and/or the analysis or synthesis of organic compounds, and present an aim, methodology and method, results, discussion and conclusion in a scientific poster.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?

ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge outlined in Area of Study 3 and the related key science skills on pages 11 and 12 of the study design.

ContentDescription: Practical work is a central component of learning and assessment and may include activities such as laboratory experiments, fieldwork, simulations and other direct experiences as described in the scientific investigation methodologies on page 13.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
Elaboration: A minimum of 10 hours of class time should be devoted to student practical activities and investigations across Areas of Study 1 and 2.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
Elaboration: For Area of Study 3, a minimum of 10 hours of class time should be devoted to designing and undertaking the student-designed scientific investigation and communicating findings.

Subject: Chemistry
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentHeader: How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
ContentDescription: The examination will be set by a panel appointed by the VCAA.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - How is scientific inquiry used to investigate the sustainable production of energy and/or materials?
